Pass in ringified a ringified block to get its specs

block-definition.comment: set first item to 'all' to allow editing of all blocks
set first item to 'all' to allow editing of all blocks

block-definition.s: toggle list item key %'key' value %'value' enabled %'enabled'
only enabled values in toggle list %'list'

custom-block.s: toggle list item key %txt value %s enabled %b

block-definition.s: item %'key' is enabled in toggle list %'list' ?
translate %'translation key' from translations %'translations' fallback language %'fallback language' missing handler %'missing handler' placeholders from list %'placeholders'
block-definition.comment: Translates the provided key from the list of translations using the following rules: Translation in language of Snap! IDE (if translation exists) Translation in fallback language (if translation exists) If no translations are found, reports the key Missing handler is an optional command to run when a translation does not exist for the IDE's current language (e.g. to log strings that need to be translated). It receives two parameters: target language and missing key. Placeholders is a list of values to substitute into placeholders in the translation string. Placeholders are formatted as $1, $2, etc. The number corresponds to the position of the placeholder in the list, starting from 1 on the left. It is recommended to wrap this block in another custom block to avoid redundancy.

custom-block.s: get translation information for %txt from translations %l fallback language %txt missing handler %s

block-definition.s: get translation information for %'translation key' from translations %'translations' fallback language %'fallback language' missing handler %'missing handler'
block-definition.comment: Reports the translated string (without filling in the placeholders) and translated language of the provided key from the list of translations using the following rules: Translation string in language of Snap! IDE (if translation exists) Translation string in fallback language (if translation exists) Translation key if no translation is found Translation language matches the language of the translation string (lagnauge of the IDE or the fallback language if the string has not been translated). If the string is not found in any language, even the fallback language, the translation language is blank. Missing handler is an optional command to run when a translation does not exist for the IDE's current language (e.g. to log strings that need to be translated). It receives two parameters: target language and missing key. You won't often need to call this block directly unless you need to know the language of the translated string. One posisble use for this is setting the accent for text-to-speech using translated text.

block.comment: If we can't find a translation for this item, just display teh inmput text
only include language that have translations
Check if each language has a translation for the given key.

block-definition.comment: Reports the language of the Snap! IDE.

block-definition.s: add missing translation to %'list' language %'language' key %'string'
block-definition.comment: Reports the list of missing translations, including the specified language/key combination. The specified language/string combination is only added if it is not already present.
Turns the JSON into a list for use in translations
Loads the sound from the specified URL and reports it

block-definition.s: load remote sound %'sound key' to list %'list'
block-definition.comment: Loads the specified remote sound and caches it to the list if it has not yet been loaded. Unlike other Remote Sounds blocks, this mutates the list.

block-definition.s: remote sound %'sound key' from sound list %'list' missing handler %'missing handler'
block-definition.comment: Reports the specified remote sound from the specified list. If the sound has not been cached in the list, it is loaded from the remote server and the list is mutated to include the cached sound. If the specified sound is not found, reports nothing. Missing handler is an optional command block that is run when the specified key is not found on the list. It receives the key as its only parameter. Helpful for keeping track of missing sounds.

block-definition.s: add missing remote audio to %'list' key %'string'
block-definition.comment: Helper to keep track of a list of missing sound keys. Only adds the key if it is not already on the list. Reports a new list with the added sound.
Retrieves the JSON sound list of keys and URLs from the specified URL and reports it as a List.

block-definition.s: speak %'text' with %'lang' accent $nl and pitch %'pitch' rate %'rate'

block-definition.s: preload remote sounds that start with %'start' from %'list'
block-definition.comment: Used to load multiple sounds at once by specifying the beginning of their key

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.s: substring of %'str' from position %'start' to position %'end' inclusive
block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input (string) starting at the position given by the second input (counting from 1, like LETTER n OF) and ending at the position given by the third input (also counting from 1). If the third input is empty, reports the portion from the first position to the end of the string. If a position number is negative, counts from the end backward, so -1 is the last character, -2 is the next to last, etc.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ entre as posições _ e _ , inclusive

block-definition.comment: Catch errors. Runs the first script. If it succeeds, nothing else happens. But if it has an error (something that would otherwise result in a red halo around the block), then the second script is run, with the text of the error message that would have been shown in the variable ERROR.
block-definition.translations: pt:tenta executar _ e, em caso de erro _ , executa _

block-definition.comment: Throw an error. Makes a red halo appear around the script that runs it, with the input text shown in a speech balloon next to the script, just like any Snap! error. This is useful to put in the second script of SAFELY TRY after some other instructions to undo the partial work of the first script.

block-definition.s: safely try reporting %'this' then if %'error' report %'that'
block-definition.comment: Catch errors in a reporter. Evaluates its first input. If that expression successfully reports a value, this block reports that value. If the expression causes a Snap! error, then the final input slot is evaluated with the text of what would have been the error message in variable ERROR. SAFELY TRY then reports the value of that final expression. Sometimes you'll want to throw an error in the final expression. You can put an ERROR block inside a CALL block to do that.
Extract mode/parameters from MW broadcast string. MW messages are broadcast in the format mode|params.
Retrieves the image at the specified URL and returns it as a costume.

Allows reading global settings programmatically. Eisenberg's Law: Anything you can do from the user interface you should be able to do in your program, and vice versa. This library is just a beginning; there are many UI controls outside of the Settings menu.

input.options: Project notes Project name User Presentation mode Language Zoom blocks Stage size Stage scale Retina display support Long form input dialog Plain prototype labels Input sliders Execute on slider change Clicking sound Turbo mode Flat design Keyboard editing Visible stepping Thread safe scripts Prefer smooth animations Flat line ends Codification support Inheritance support Hyper blocks support Visible palette

block.l: var stage = this.parentThatIsA(StageMorph), ide = stage.parentThatIsA(IDE_Morph), world = stage.parentThatIsA(WorldMorph); switch (which) { case 'Project notes': return ide.projectNotes; case 'Project name': return ide.projectName; case 'User': return ide.cloud.username; case 'Presentation mode': return ide.isAppMode; case 'Language': return SnapTranslator.language; case 'Zoom blocks': return SyntaxElementMorph.prototype.scale; case 'Stage size': return new List([StageMorph.prototype.dimensions.x, StageMorph.prototype.dimensions.y]); case 'Stage scale': return stage.scale; case 'Retina display support': return isRetinaEnabled(); case 'Long form input dialog': return InputSlotDialogMorph.prototype.isLaunchingExpanded; case 'Plain prototype labels': return BlockLabelPlaceHolderMorph.prototype.plainLabel; case 'Input sliders': return MorphicPreferences.useSliderForInput; case 'Execute on slider change': return ArgMorph.prototype.executeOnSliderEdit; case 'Clicking sound': return !!BlockMorph.prototype.snapSound; case 'Turbo mode': return stage.isFastTracked; case 'Flat design': return MorphicPreferences.isFlat; case 'Keyboard editing': return !!this.scripts.focus; case 'Visible stepping': return Process.prototype.enableSingleStepping; case 'Thread safe scripts': return stage.isThreadSafe; case 'Prefer smooth animations': return StageMorph.prototype.frameRate > 0; case 'Flat line ends': return SpriteMorph.prototype.useFlatLineEnds; case 'Codification support': return StageMorph.prototype.enableCodeMapping; case 'Inheritance support': return StageMorph.prototype.enableInheritance; case 'Hyper blocks support': return Process.prototype.enableHyperOps; default: return which; case 'Visible palette': return ide.currentCategory; }

block-definition.comment: Allows changing global settings programmatically. This block is for Boolean (checkbox) settings; use SET VALUE for numeric or text values. Eisenberg's Law: Anything you can do from the user interface you should be able to do in your program, and vice versa. This library is just a beginning; there are many UI controls outside of the Settings menu.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera o valor da configuração _ para _

input.options: Presentation mode Retina display support Long form input dialog Plain prototype labels Input sliders Execute on slider change Clicking sound Turbo mode Flat design Keyboard editing Visible stepping Thread safe scripts Prefer smooth animations Flat line ends Codification support Inheritance support Hyper blocks support

block.l: var stage = this.parentThatIsA(StageMorph), ide = stage.parentThatIsA(IDE_Morph), world = stage.parentThatIsA(WorldMorph), thisObj = this; if (tf != !!tf) return; try{ ide.savingPreferences = false; switch (which) { case 'Presentation mode': if (tf != ide.isAppMode) ide.toggleAppMode(); break; case 'Retina display support': if (tf != isRetinaEnabled()) ide.toggleRetina(); break; case 'Long form input dialog': if (tf != InputSlotDialogMorph.prototype.isLaunchingExpanded) ide.toggleLongFormInputDialog(); break; case 'Plain prototype labels': if (tf != BlockLabelPlaceHolderMorph.prototype.plainLabel) ide.togglePlainPrototypeLabels(); break; case 'Input sliders': MorphicPreferences.useSliderForInput = tf; break; case 'Execute on slider change': ArgMorph.prototype.executeOnSliderEdit = tf; break; case 'Clicking sound': if (tf != !!BlockMorph.prototype.snapSound) BlockMorph.prototype.toggleSnapSound(); break; case 'Turbo mode': if (tf != stage.isFastTracked) ide.toggleFastTracking(); break; case 'Flat design': if (tf == MorphicPreferences.isFlat) break; if (tf) ide.flatDesign(); else ide.defaultDesign(); break; case 'Keyboard editing': if (thisObj.scripts.focus && !tf) { thisObj.scripts.focus.stopEditing(); } else if (tf && !thisObj.scripts.focus) { thisObj.scripts.toggleKeyboardEntry(); }; break; case 'Visible stepping': if (tf != Process.prototype.enableSingleStepping) ide.toggleSingleStepping(); break; case 'Thread safe scripts': stage.isThreadSafe = tf; break; case 'Prefer smooth animations': if (tf != (StageMorph.prototype.frameRate > 0)) ide.toggleVariableFrameRate(); break; case 'Flat line ends': SpriteMorph.prototype.useFlatLineEnds = tf; break; case 'Codification support': if (tf != StageMorph.prototype.enableCodeMapping) { StageMorph.prototype.enableCodeMapping = tf; ide.currentSprite.blocksCache.variables = null; ide.currentSprite.paletteCache.variables = null; ide.refreshPalette(); } break; case 'Inheritance support': if (tf != StageMorph.prototype.enableInheritance) { StageMorph.prototype.enableInheritance = tf; ide.currentSprite.blocksCache.variables = null; ide.currentSprite.paletteCache.variables = null; ide.refreshPalette(); } break; case 'Hyper blocks support': Process.prototype.enableHyperOps = tf; break; }; } finally { ide.savingPreferences = false; };

block-definition.comment: Allows changing global settings programmatically. This block is for numeric or text settings; use SET FLAG for Boolean (checkbox) values. Eisenberg's Law: Anything you can do from the user interface you should be able to do in your program, and vice versa. This library is just a beginning; there are many UI controls outside of the Settings menu.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera o valor da configuração _ para _

input.options: Project notes Project name Language Zoom blocks Stage size Stage scale Visible palette

block.l: var stage = this.parentThatIsA(StageMorph), ide = stage.parentThatIsA(IDE_Morph), world = stage.parentThatIsA(WorldMorph); try { ide.savingPreferences = false; switch (which) { case 'Project notes': ide.projectNotes = value; break; case 'Project name': ide.setProjectName(value); break; case 'Language': ide.setLanguage(value); break; case 'Zoom blocks': if (!isNaN(value)) ide.setBlocksScale(Math.min(value, 12)); break; case 'Stage size': if ((value instanceof List) && value.length()==2 && !isNaN(value.at(1)) && !isNaN(value.at(2))) ide.setStageExtent(new Point(value.at(1), value.at(2))); break; case 'Stage scale': ide.toggleStageSize(value != 1, Math.max(0.1, value)); break; case 'Visible palette': ide.currentCategory = value.toLowerCase(); ide.categories.children.forEach(function (each) { each.refresh(); }); ide.refreshPalette(true); break; }; } finally {ide.savingPreferences = true; };

block-definition.comment: This block creates new variables on the selected scope: global (for all sprites), sprite (for this sprite only) or script (only for that blocks stack) with the names given (in 'names' list). If there is already a variable with that name in that scope, it does nothing: no errors and no overwrites.
block-definition.translations: pt:cria as variáveis _ _ ca:crea les _ variables _ es:crear las _ variables _ de:erstellen _ var _

scripts.comment: All the Remote Sounds blocks in one place to demonstrate usage and make exporting relevant blocks easier. If you are creating a new microworld, you can delete this sprite.

custom-block.comment: Load extension Optional - all blocks that require extensions will load them automatically the first time they're run. However, loading up front will prevent delays later in the script.

block.comment: List to keep track fo remote sounds. Stores a URL for unloaded sounds which is replaced by the cached sound after loading. If storing remote sounds as a variable, make sure it's transient to prevent the cached sounds from saving into the project.

add missing remote audio to %l key %s

custom-block.comment: If the specified key isn't found in the specified list, it will be added to the (missing sounds) variable. Can be used to automatically test for missing sounds.

block-definition.comment: Sets the current puzzle to the specified key. As long as the key is in the format [some word(s)] [number], the prefix will automatically be extracted and translated in necessary labels.

inputs.input: top righttop left top right bottom left bottom right

block-definition.s: set up puzzle buttons for set %'set key'
text area called %'key' size: %'size' font: %'font' align: %'align' x: %'x' y: %'y' color: %'color'

inputs.input: Arialserif sans-serif monospace Arial Arial Black Verdana Tahoma Trebuchet MS Impact Times New Roman Didot Georgia American Typewriter Andalé Mono Courier Lucida Console Monaco Bradley Hand Brush Script MT Luminari Comic Sans MS

block-definition.s: set eraser color r: %'r' g: %'g' b: %'b'

scripts.comment: When building a microworld from scratch, no other special instructions needed. When converting an existing project to a MW using this base: 1. Export from this base (a) all blocks; (b) the Microworld base sprite; (c) the Custom Microworld sprite; 2. Import those IN THAT ORDER into your existing project; 3. Modify the script below (as noted) and modify your project (as needed) to use it. THIS BASE IS UPDATED PERIODICALLY, for improvements or to adjust to updates in Snap!. If you are working from a copy you've kept, you may need to perform your own updates.
Places where DESIGNER must modify are marked. Otherwise, use this script as given.

Other comments are documentation, but generally should not be modified. Required sprites: Microworld base, Custom Microworld (can be renamed), User, Puzzler. Other sprites in this microworld base serve only to highlight capabilities. They are not needed for Designer-generated MWs and can be deleted.
Look at blue custom blocks for examples of what you can do. You will probably want to delete their definitions or modify them for your microworld.

custom-block.l:
{ "en": { "Exploration 1.text": "Drag out blocks
and click on them.", "Exploration 2.text": "Build a script
that ...", "Puzzle 1.text": "Make a script that moves me
to the right of the screen.", "Puzzle 2.text": "Make a script that moves me
to the bottom left of the screen." }, "es": { "Exploration 1.text": "Arrastre los bloques 
y haga clic en ellos.", "Exploration 2.text": "Crea un script 
que ...", "Puzzle 1.text": "Crea un script ...", "Puzzle 2.text": "Crea un script ...", "Exploration $1": "Exploración $1", "Puzzle $1": "Rompecabeza $1", "Challenge $1": "Desafío $1", "Add and Subtract 1s, 10s, 100s": "Sumar y Restar 1, 10, 100", "Click here to start.": "Haz click aquí para comenzar." } }
custom-block.comment: DESIGNER specifies puzzle text and translations

custom-block.s: puzzle %br $ -1 key: %txt %br $ -1 puzzler x: %n %br $ -1 puzzler y: %n
puzzle %br $ -1 key: %txt %br $ -1 puzzler x: %n %br $ -1 puzzler y: %n
custom-block.comment: DESIGNER modifies PUZZLE block: include all needed puzzle parameters (sprites, costumes, special graphics/videos, changes in palette block specs, new buttons, etc.)

custom-block.s: puzzle %br $ -1 key: %txt %br $ -1 puzzler x: %n %br $ -1 puzzler y: %n
puzzle %br $ -1 key: %txt %br $ -1 puzzler x: %n %br $ -1 puzzler y: %n
custom-block.comment: key is puzzle title in English; see use of other puzzle params below in DESIGNER PUZZLE FRAME
DESIGNER OPTIONAL: Edit this block to initialize variables, sizes and visibility of sprites, stage, etc.

scripts.comment: note that puzzle titles (e.g., Exploration, Puzzle, Challenge) match across languages and that translations of those titles and the intro banner are specified after puzzle text.

custom-block.comment: Modify URL if project is not EDC-connected or NSF-funded.
DESIGNER generally modifies "title" only

custom-block.s: set eraser color r: %n g: %n b: %n
custom-block.comment: DESIGNER, if stage color is not white, change this

custom-block.s: text area called %txt size: %n font: %s align: %txt x: %n y: %n color: %txt
custom-block.comment: This area must exist so that the puzzle label is drawn correctly. Can be moved to a different location on the stage.

block.comment: One place to handle updating labels on the screen (curent puzzle #, etc) Any time the screen is cleared or one of these values changes, BROADCAST 'redraw stage labels'

block.l: close intro banner and start puzzles

custom-block.comment: DESIGNER, if Stage is not to be blank, edit here.

block.comment: DESIGNER initializes sprites' show, size, and costumes

custom-block.comment: If the block specs should be the same for all puzzles and sets, you can specify them here. Otherwise, they can be specified as puzzle parameters and set in the PUZZLE FRAME section of the 'when I receive any message' script.
DESIGNER: PALETTE SPECIFICATION
DESIGNER: Set special buttons here and include actions below. See DESIGNER BUTTON ACTIONS below.

block.comment: Used to interpret messages for puzzles and puzzle sets. Useful for changing the behavior of microworlds and creating new microworlds. If you only want to add/remove/change the TEXT of puzzles or add translations, you likely don't need to modify anything in this section.

custom-block.s: set up puzzle buttons for set %txt

block.comment: Starts the first puzzle in the set

custom-block.s: set current puzzle %txt with text placeholders %l label location %txt
say %mlt at my %s with text size %n font: %txt color: %txt

block.comment: DESIGNER PUZZLE FRAME: Make script of "frame" of all puzzles. Specify all actions of a puzzle. Add whatever other handlers you need for the puzzle here as well.
MUST be the last block in this "if" Otherwise, broadcasting a new message will terminate the remainder of this script.
DESIGNER BUTTON ACTIONS (example): for each button, insert new IF, and name the button and insert script to perform action
DESIGNER: Specify what options you want the user to have in each menu.

custom-block.l: help..., 0, duplicate, duplicate single block, extract
undrop, redrop, 0, clean up, add comment

custom-block.s: hidden UI features %br %b sprite bar %br %b sprite corral %br palette %br $ -1 %b category list %br $ -1 %b make block buttons %br $ -1 %b search button %br control bar %br $ -1 %b stepping button %br $ -1 %b start button %br $ -1 %b pause button

custom-block.comment: DESIGNER: All designer-created blocks are non-editable by default, so empty input here means disables editing of all blocks (other than those created inside the microworld).
